The project explores two approaches to optimize building energy consumption. The first approach combines a linear load forecasting model with convex optimization to achieve an optimal solution. The second approach combines a nonlinear load forecasting model with nonconvex optimization to achieve a locally optimal solution. The project evaluates these approaches using a simulation testbed in EnergyPlus and experiments in buildings on a university campus.

Building energy consumption accounts for one-third of the United States' greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, the largest of any sector (EPA, 2021). The Biden administration has set a target of reducing 2005 GHG emissions by 50% by 2030 and achieving net zero emissions by 2050 (White-House, 2021). To achieve these targets, the US must create energy-efficient new buildings and lower energy consumption in existing buildings. A significant fraction of GHG emissions in buildings is due to heating and air conditioning, which account for about one-third of energy consumption in residential buildings and 17% in commercial buildings (EIA, 2021a, 2021b).

To reduce heating and cooling demands, many energy systems and building envelope technologies are being implemented. However, these are capital-intensive. An alternative approach is to adjust building temperature set-points to lower energy consumption and GHG emissions. This approach has two components: reducing heating or cooling when a space is unoccupied by learning behavioral patterns, and timing electricity-derived heating or cooling to coincide with low GHG emissions from the electrical grid.

Adjusting building temperature set-points requires little capital investment and may only require changes to software and/or thermostats. Given that US residential and commercial GHG emissions are nearly the same (EPA, 2021), there is a significant opportunity to implement building temperature set-point machine learning algorithms for commercial buildings. This is a challenging task due to the scale and complexity of commercial buildings and their management systems.

The application of machine learning methods to commercial building heating and cooling systems is a well-studied field. Previous research has categorized these applications into three areas: building energy modeling, optimizing energy use, and occupancy prediction (Rolnick et al., 2019; Esrafiilian-Najafabadi & Haghighat, 2021). The proposed project will eventually span all three categories, but this paper focuses on building energy modeling and optimizing energy use.

The primary contribution of the proposed project will be experimental validation in a real building, which has been instrumented with energy submeters, people counters, and other sensors. A secondary contribution will be optimizing GHG emissions, rather than more common performance criteria such as energy consumption and operating costs.

The proposed GHG minimization framework involves two steps: (1) learning a model to predict energy consumption based on temperature set-points and other features, and (2) using the learned model and daily predictions of occupancy and the GHG intensity of electricity to decide set-point profiles that minimize GHG emissions.
